awd_titl_txt: WSU Students ASK: A Success & Scholarship Program for Students Applying Scientific Knowledge
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, the "WSU Students ASK: A Success and Scholarship Program for Students Applying Scientific Knowledge" will support high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need.  The program focuses on supporting the success of mathematics and science majors at Wright State University. This S-STEM Track 2 project is expected to last five years and will provide scholarships to 42 financially at-risk students majoring in science and mathematics.  The scholarships will begin in the students' second year of college.  The project includes a comprehensive mentoring and experiential learning pathway to support students' academic and career development.

All scholarship students will participate in at least one year of undergraduate research.  During their second year in college (first year in the program), scholarship recipients will enroll in a classroom-based undergraduate research experience, then join a faculty research team for one semester.  The program will support students who want to continue their research through the summer.  In their third year, students can continue to pursue research, or participate in external internships and related opportunities.  The fourth year focuses on assisting students with career placement and/or application to graduate or professional programs. The project team will conduct research that can contribute new knowledge about the impact of experiential learning coupled with financial aid on scientific skill set development, STEM community membership, and academic success. Program assessment will include a mixed-methods approach that combines qualitative methods, network analysis, and statistical modeling. Since Wright State has an academically heterogeneous student body compared to many other undergraduate research institutions, the project team will focus on a study of factors that help to scale the many positive effects of this program to a more diverse population of students. The project has the potential to generate new knowledge about four dimensions (experiential STEM learning, membership in the STEM community, skill development, and academic success) relevant to the success of low-income, academically talented students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Applying Scientific Knowledge (ASK) Program, an experiential learning initiative within the College of Science and Mathematics at Wright State University, is designed to provide early undergraduate students with access to research opportunities on campus. The program’s key objectives include:

  • Awarding at least three-year scholarships over a five-year period to talented, financial-aid-eligible science and math majors, typically beginning in their second year at WSU.
  • Offering an innovative experiential learning process through team-based research participation.
  • Implementing a faculty mentoring system for ASK S-STEM Scholars to support their academic progression, facilitate placement in research labs and internships, and guide career selection.
  • Assessing and evaluating the impact of experiential learning combined with financial aid on the development of scientific skills, STEM community engagement, and academic success.

ASK Program participants engage directly in cutting-edge research with College of Science and Mathematics faculty at Wright State University, allowing them to immerse themselves in research experiences that bridge the gap between coursework and scientific practice. The program primarily targets students entering their second year, with some first-year students who have significant course credit also being admitted.

All scholarship recipients participate in at least one year of undergraduate research. In their second year of college (first year in the program), students enroll in a classroom-based undergraduate research experience and subsequently join a faculty research team for one semester. The program also supports students who wish to continue their research through the summer. In their third year, students may continue their research or participate in external internships and related opportunities. The fourth year focuses on assisting students with career placement and/or applications to graduate or professional programs.

The project team conduct research aimed at generating new insights into the impact of experiential learning coupled with financial aid on the development of scientific skills, STEM community membership, and academic success. The program's assessment utilize a mixed-methods approach, combining qualitative methods, network analysis, and statistical modeling. Given Wright State’s academically diverse student body compared to many other undergraduate research institutions, the project team will also study factors that help scale the positive effects of this program to a broader and more diverse student population. This project has the potential to contribute valuable knowledge across four key dimensions—experiential STEM learning, STEM community engagement, skill development, and academic success—particularly in the context of supporting low-income, academically talented students.

Project Outcome: The ASK program's key innovation was the creation of a 3-credit course designed to equip participants with essential skills for success in undergraduate research. Additionally, the program implemented a faculty mentor-student researcher matching process, effectively reducing barriers to student participation in research activities. The ASK program director initiated a call for faculty proposals, requiring faculty to submit a mentor form that outlined the project description, expected time commitment, and the number of available student slots. After the initial matching, students met with potential mentors to mutually decide if the partnership was a good fit. If it was not, the student was paired with another faculty member from their priority list.

Many scholarship recipients have been co-authors on publications, as listed in the products section of this report. Additionally, many students participated in and presented their research at the annual College of Science and Mathematics Festival of Research, where several earned top scholar prizes.

ASK program students actively participate in Career Development Workshops organized by the College of Science and Mathematics at Wright State University. In collaboration with other units within the college and university, the ASK program has offered workshops such as "Science and Math Students: Social Media for the Job Search," "Key Strategies for Interview Success," "How to be Career Ready," and various other professional development opportunities.

The ASK program awarded a total of 111 student-semester scholarships over the entire life of the award. More than 76% of ASK scholarship recipients are currently pursuing graduate or professional education in a STEM field or are employed in areas closely aligned with their undergraduate education. Additionally, the graduation rate for ASK scholarship recipients is 87%. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 08/28/2024
Modified by: Steven R Higgins
